data.title: Born A King, Dies An Outcast
data.meta_description: Ex-King Alfonso of Spain died In Rome today propped up in a special armchair from which he could not be moved because of his asthmatic condition.  ...

Just before he died he re-

marked to ex-Queen Ena,

from whom he had been

estranged for six years: —

'I hope my death will not dis

tress Don Juan— his third son

who is heir to the throne— too

much. He must learn that kings

must suffer and be brave.'

Then he called Juan to his side,

murmured: 'Your Majesty— Spain be.

fore all.'

Then he summoned a Spanish

Jesuit priest and prepared for the

end.

It was stated recently in Lisbon

that Alfonso had signed a document

giving Don Juan full right to ascend

the Spanish throne, if invited to do

so.

Born A King

Ex-King Alfonso XIII of Spain was

literally born a king. The posthu

mous son of King Alfonso XII of

Spain, Alfonso himself became King

of Spain in name on the day of his

birth, May 17, 1886.

Sixteen years later (his mother

in the meantime having acted as

regent), he ascended the throne

to assume its full powers and

obligations.

When the revolution of 1931 broke

out and he left the country to go into

exile, he refused to abdicate formally.

On the contrary, he issued a mani

festo on April 15, 1931, the day after

he left, declaring, 'I am King of all

Spaniards ... I renounce no single

one of my rights.'

Don Alfonso's life was stormy.

During the 29 years he was on

the throne, there were eight at

tempts to assassinate him.

The most dramatic of these was on

May 31, 1906, the day of his wedding

to the English princess, Victoria

Eugenia Ena of Battenburg, niece of

King Edward VII.

The plots against Alfonso's life,

however, dated much farther back.

In fact, on the very day he was

crowned (May 17, 1902), secret

police thwarted an attempt t to as

sassinate the 16-year-old king.

Many Changes

When Alfonso ascended the throne

the country was in a very bad state

economically. Distress was prevalent.

Socialism and anarchism began to be

come real forces; discontent was rife;

trouble, rioting and finally war broke

out in Morocco (lasting until 1926).

Change after change was tried

in the administration, there being

20 cabinets in one period of six

years.

As captain-general of Barcelona,

Primo de Rivera in 1923 headed a

bloodless coup d'etat and made him

self dictator. King Alfonso did not

move against the general, but invited

him to take charge of the Government

when the Cabinet resigned. The part

nership of King and Dictator lasted

six years.

Republican and other liberal lead

ers who had been exiled since 1923

then came back and a flood of agita

tion against monarchial institutions

was released.

In 1931 a republic was pro

claimed at Barcelona and the

movement spread quickly. The

Republican leaders presented

their ultimatum — abdication or

revolution.

The King had promised that he

would not plunge his country into

civil war; he kept his promise, at the

price of his throne.

The new Republic of Spain tried

the ex-King for high treason in his

absence. He was found guilty; his

goods and property were declared

forfeit, and he was condemned to per

petual banishment.

Family Troubles

The ex-King, who had gone to

France, then became involved in a

series of family worries and cares.

In 1935, there was an estrangement

from his wife, ex-Queen Victoria

Eugenia.

The year before, his eldest son, and

heir to the throne, Alfonso Prince of

Asturias, had married a commoner,

the Cuban, Edelmira Sanpedro-Ocejo,

against his father's wishes.

Don Alfonso insisted that his

son give up his rights to the

throne. This was done and he

was created Count of Covadonga.

In 1935 Alfonso lost his youngest

son, Don Gonzalo. Alfonso's second

son, Don Jaime then followed his

eldest brother's example and relin

quished his rights to the throne.

Alfonso was described as one of

the richest monarchs of his time. Pre

cise figures were never made public,

but it was known that he inherited a

personal fortune of several millions,

which he increased materially by in

vestments in British and other securi

ties.
